question: Is perceived facial age, controlling for chronological age and sex, significantly correlated with leukocyte telomere length in adults aged 70 and older? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Perceived age, controlled for chronological age and sex, also correlated significantly with physical and cognitive functioning as well as with leucocyte telomere length.
content.source_2: In a population-based cohort, after adjustment for chronological age, sex, and lifestyle covariates, perceived age was unrelated to physical or cognitive function and did not associate with leucocyte telomere length.
content.source_3: CONCLUSION Perceived age-which is widely used by clinicians as a general indication of a patient's health-is a robust biomarker of ageing that predicts survival among those aged >or=70 and correlates with important functional and molecular ageing phenotypes.
content.source_4: In a multicentre study of adults aged â‰¥70 with five years of follow-up, perceived age did not operate as a robust biomarker of ageing and failed to predict survival once smoking status, comorbidity burden, and education were included in the model; associations with functional and molecular phenotypes were weak and inconsistent.
